description:
So a breakthrough in New York last night: Russia and the United States committed themselves to establishing a unity government in Syria within months despite continuing differences over the future role of President Assad.

The commitment was included in a roadmap to peace adopted unanimously by the United Nations Security Council. The resolution calls for ceasefire across the country and UN-supervised elections there within 18 months. Mark Urban says significant progress was clearly made in New York, but an end to the war remains a distant prospect.

Many years ago in Damascus, I found the tables turned on me by the Syrian foreign minister. He was aware that actually I was based in Jerusalem. And back then in the mid-90s, travellers coming from Israel were still quite a rarity in that minister's office. So when I'd filmed my interview, he started his about the Israeli appetite for peace and the sincerity of their prime minister. He asked more questions than I had, cross examining me intensely. And all the time, he didn't mention certain things, very obvious ones, like where I was based or the senior Israelis I'd recently interviewed. Everything was implicit. It was a master class in diplomacy Damascus style of not showing your hand. And given that Israel and Syria didn't make peace, it was also an object lesson in how you can keep diplomatic hope alive when government's public positions were clearly irreconcilable.
